Award.AbstractNarration:
The fundamental research question posed by this project is how to provide an integrated, flexible, and scalable storage repository for early design sketches. Early design is characterized by informal, unstructured, and heavily collaborative work processes involving multiple participants, multiple forms of representational media, and a plethora of interactions between these. However, there currently exist no storage mechanisms capable of supporting the full scope of sketching for creative design. In practice, designers either resort to low-tech physical artifacts such as pen, paper, and whiteboards that lack the persistence of digital storage, or general purpose software such as e-mail or shared file systems where the storage mechanisms are not well-integrated with the creative process and also lack provenance, history, and versioning information.

Intellectual Merit: The contribution of this project is to apply the concept of a Wiki to sketches. Wikis are collections of freely editable web documents and have become popular due to their capacity for drawing upon the crowd to create content. Wikis have also been shown to be particularly useful in early design, but existing Wiki software makes integrating visual representations burdensome. This research effort will be focused on designing, building, and evaluating a sketch-based Wiki (skWiki) that allows for combining vectorized sketches with text.

Broader Impacts: Unlike prototyping, manufacturing, or even engineering, innovation cannot easily be outsourced and is now recognized as the single most important ingredient in our economy. Consequently, there has never been a clearer imperative to both create designs which will fundamentally change the competitive landscape, and also to improve the innovative capacity of designers, particularly those in engineering. To facilitate such synergistic effects, the skWiki framework designed in this project will be made available as Open Source. We will also use the tool for teaching engineering design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the skWiki project was to design, build, and evaluate a Wiki that is capable of storing sketches for creative design. Wikis are online and freely editable collections of web documents and have been shown to be particularly useful to coordinate, capture, and support early design. However, traditional Wiki software lack capabilities to easily edit, revise, and merge visual representations such as sketches. The project successfully created such a Wiki-like system called skWiki (pronounced Squeaky) that is particularly suited for capturing early design sketching for virtually any design discipline, including industrial design, interface design, and software design.

Intellectual Merit: The skWiki project has had four major intellectual outcomes:

  • Sketches on Wikis: The first part of the project was to create the basic skWiki framework that supports sketching in the browser. This required creating a graphical editor that goes beyond current Wiki editors and provides full sketch-based support. (Published in CHI 2014).
  • The Path Model: To facilitate multiple designers working together on a sketch, we introduced a novel persistent mechanism that goes beyond normal files. Instead of storing a snapshot of the state of a digital object for a particular point in time, a path stores each of the operations that have transformed the digital object from its creation to its current state. This allows for maintaining consistency and history of a sketch, as well as easily branching from a sketch at any time.
  • Digital and paper-based design: One practical aspect of sketching on tablets instead of paper is that the digital medium has different affordances and capabilities than paper. In a recent project, we evaluated these differences for low-level shape tracing tasks, and found that appropriate hard-tipped styli can provide comparable performance to paper, but that paper still is superior in terms of the quality of sketches. (Published in AVI 2014.)
  • Merging in creative design: Our most recent work within the skWiki project has been to study merging: a canonical task in collaborative work, where a designer combines two or more artifacts into a single one. In current practice, this is often done due to one of two reasons: (a) convergence, where the goal is to combine the best features of two ideas into a single one, or (b) divergence, where the goal is to use features from the two separate ideas to create an entirely new idea. We have studied interface, interaction, and algorithm designs for this task in terms of sketching, and evaluated them with human subject experiments. We are currently working on implementing the findings into the skWiki software system. (Submitted to an HCI conference.)

Broader Impact: Beyond the scientific output of the project, a key practical outcome that the project so far has produced is an initial Open Source distribution of the skWiki system for collaborative sharing of sketches. This Open Source distribution of skWiki can be accessed on the following GitHub page:

https://github.com/karthikbadam/skWiki

Going forward, we anticipate continuing development on the skWiki system to make it a stable and robust platform for creative design in both educational and professional settings. We have received interested from Purdue’s instructional software development department for possibly continuing this development on a more rigorous level. We are continuing to explore these options.
